Abstrak:
The hunt for gravitational waves is on again — this time assisted by the
quirks of quantum mechanics. Three massive detectors — two in the
United States called LIGO and one in Italy known as Virgo — resumed collecting data
on 1 April, after a 19-month shutdown for upgrades. Thanks in part to a quantum
phenomenon known as light squeezing, the machines promise not only to spot more
gravitational waves — ripples in space-time that can reveal a wealth of information about the cosmos — but also to make more detailed detections than before. Researchers hope to observe as-yet undetected events, such as a supernova or the merging of a black hole with a neutron star.
Fakultas: Fakultas Matematika dan Ilmu Pengetahuan Alam
